Cyc Quickstart

Welcome!

This quickstart is for OpenCyc 5.0-preview and newer.

Other pages are available for EnterpriseCyc 1.7-preview and ResearchCyc 4.0q.

Installation

Download!

Copy the archive into a directory, and then untar or unzip the compressed archive.

On Linux, run the following command in a terminal:

tar -xvzf opencyc-5.0-preview-rc5.tgz

On Windows, unzip the opencyc-5.0-preview-rc5.zip file.

This will create a directory named opencyc-5.0-preview-rc5 in your current directory.

Launching Cyc

Linux

From within opencyc-5.0-preview-rc5/cyc, execute the following command:

./bin/run-cyc.sh

This will launch OpenCyc on its default base port, 3600. Cyc will begin to stream status messages to the terminal as it loads.

You may specify other base ports: 3620, 3640, 3660, or 3680. For example, to launch on port 3660:

./bin/run-cyc-60.sh

Do not close the terminal window; doing so will kill the image. To run Cyc as a daemon, use the Screen utility as described below. To shut down Cyc cleanly, see the Shutting down Cyc section at the end of this document.

Linux, using Screen

If you have the GNU Screen utility installed, you may wish to use it to launch Cyc. Screen allows Cyc to be run as a daemon, and closing the terminal window will not kill it.

From within opencyc-5.0-preview-rc5/cyc, execute the following command:

screen -dmS opencyc-00 bash -c "./bin/run-cyc-00.sh"

This will start Cyc in a detached screen session named “opencyc-00”. Note that because the session is detached, you initially won’t see any output from Cyc.

You can attach to this session from any terminal with following command:

screen -rd opencyc-00

To detach from the screen (while still leaving it running): Ctrl-a d

To see a list of all screen sessions:

screen -list

Of course, you may also specify other ports. For example, to launch on port 3660:

screen -dmS opencyc-60 bash -c "./bin/run-cyc-60.sh"

Note that here we’ve named this session “opencyc-60”; you can attach to it with screen -rd opencyc-60.

Lastly, note that killing the shell (via Ctrl-c) will still kill the Cyc image. To shut down Cyc cleanly, see the Shutting down Cyc section at the end of this document.

Windows

To launch Cyc:

  1. Navigate to the directory opencyc-5.0-preview-rc5\cyc
  2. Double-click the file go-cyc.bat

This will launch OpenCyc on its default base port, 3600. A console will open and begin filling with status messages as Cyc loads.

Do not close the console window; doing so will kill the image. To shut down Cyc cleanly, see the Shutting down Cyc section at the end of this document.

Using Cyc

When OpenCyc is started, it loads the KB into memory; depending on the amount of RAM on your system and the speed of your disk, this can take between one and two minutes.

Once OpenCyc is running, you will see:

CYC(1):

This is the SubL command prompt. Unless you started Cyc via the Screen utility (see above), don’t close the window containing this prompt; doing so will kill the image.

Optional: You can enter SubL expressions at the command line to verify Cyc’s operation. Some examples:

(+ 1 2)

(genls #$Person)

(all-genls #$Person)

The Cyc Browser

At this point the Cyc HTTP server is running and you can access Cyc directly via a local web browser. If you started Cyc on its default base port of 3600, navigate to:

http://localhost:3602/

The browser’s port is always Cyc’s base port + 2. For example, if you started Cyc on base port 3660, you would go to http://localhost:3662/.

To access Cyc from a remote machine, change ‘localhost’ to the hostname of the machine running Cyc. For example:

http://hamlet.mydomain.com:3602/

You can browse Cyc via the Guest account or perform updates by logging on as CycAdministrator.

Java APIs and code samples

The OpenCyc API is no longer supported, and has been replaced by the new Core API Suite.

To download the Core API Suite, or for documentation, code samples, or to ask questions, visit the Cyc Developer Center.

Shutting down Cyc

To cleanly shut down the OpenCyc server, enter the following at the SubL command prompt:

CYC(N): (halt-cyc-image)
